channel.title: String.contains() is bad
channel.description:
using the .contains(str) method on a string reduces performance down a FUCKLOAD. I discovered this when testing the 'Infinite monkey theorem' (don't ask) with a friend, the method was taking the iterations down to a couple of thousand every 5 seconds, so I came up with this:
[code]if(str.length() >= substr.length() && str.substring(str.length()-substr.length()).equals(substr)) {[/code]
which has taken performance up to a few million iterations every 5 seconds.
thoughts??

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:12, topic:347487”]array access on the jvm is fairly slow due to bound checks among other shit, not to mention string processing is kind of expensive to begin with.

write it in c if you are concerned about speed
hell, why not write it in asm!11![/quote]
JIT etc…

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

public boolean endsWith(StringBuilder builder, String s) { int offset = s.length(); int typedOffset = builder.length() - offset; int sOffset = 0; if (typedOffset < 0) { return false; } while (--offset >= 0) { if (builder.charAt(typedOffset++) != s.charAt(sOffset++)) { return false; } } return true; }
Even faster way of doing it on a string builder.

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

you’re probably best off using a hash

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

array access on the jvm is fairly slow due to bound checks among other shit, not to mention string processing is kind of expensive to begin with.

write it in c if you are concerned about speed
hell, why not write it in asm!11!

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:10, topic:347487”]iirc all the code in string.contains() is [tt]return this.indexOf(other) != -1;[/tt] that cant affect performance much

but since you are only appending to the end of the string there is no need for that, since indexOf will look through every character for a match and then check the following characters as well[/quote]
Well he is using a StringBuilder so technically it would be faster to do StringBuilder.indexOf() > -1 than StringBuilder.toString().contains().
But that is beside the point, he meant to use String.endsWith and this is an alternative way of doing it directly on the StringBuilder as a pose to creating a new String object then doing String.endsWith().

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

iirc all the code in string.contains() is [tt]return this.indexOf(other) != -1;[/tt] that cant affect performance much

but since you are only appending to the end of the string there is no need for that, since indexOf will look through every character for a match and then check the following characters as well

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

endsWith was actually what was required he just didn’t think about it.
it was logically incorrect using contains when all he needed was endsWith.

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

frank_:

whats the point in looking for speed when your algorithm is logically incorrect, ie using endswith where contains was required

contains won’t be required. I’m only appending characters to the end of the string, so I only need to check where the string was affected rather than the ENTIRE string.

Read full topic

But he is looking for speed.
btw this should be a comparison to endsWith though as frank_ said seeing as contains serves a different purpose.

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

frank_ the difference is to do endsWith on a StringBuilder you have to create a String object his method you can do straight on the StringBuilder hence why it’s faster. You aren’t creating that extra String object.

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

using .endsWith() is still worse than what I posted.

With .endsWith():

[com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 63383 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 88401 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 107419 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 122336 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 135230

With what I posted:

[com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 21495960 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 44363634 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 68695255 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 90252786 [com.a.imonkey.Monkey-1] Current length: 115118153

See, it’s not even a small difference…

Side note: I’m using StringBuilder to hold the string to be searched for, and String for the substring

Read full topic

item.title: String.contains() is bad
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

except your code is doing the equivalent of String.endsWith()
